sub_topic: Calculation of Gibbs free energy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
Calculate the Gibbs free energy change for the combustion of methane gas to produce carbon dioxide and water vapor at a temperature of 298K and a pressure of 1 atm, given the equation:
CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)    ΔG°f = -394.36 kJ/mol (CO2);  ΔG°f = -237.13 kJ/mol (H2O); ΔG°f = -50.8 kJ/mol (CH4);   ΔG°f = 0 kJ/mol (O2)
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) for the combustion of methane, we can use the following equation:

ΔG° = Σ(ΔG°f products) - Σ(ΔG°f reactants)

where ΔG°f represents the standard Gibbs free energy of formation for each species involved in the reaction.

For the given reaction, we have:

ΔG° = [1 × (-394.36 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-237.13 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-50.8 kJ/mol) + 2 × 0 kJ/mol]

ΔG° = (-394.36 - 474.26 + 50.8) kJ/mol

ΔG° = -817.82 kJ/mol

So, the Gibbs free energy change for the combustion of methane gas to produce carbon dioxide and water vapor at a temperature of 298K and a pressure of 1 atm is -817.82 kJ/mol.
